stem: A client with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) is being managed with an insulin infusion. Based on the documentation in the DKA-Potassium & Insulin Trajectory Log, why must the nurse add potassium to the IV fluids even though the client's potassium was 5.8 mEq/L on admission?

options.text: Insulin causes an intracellular shift of potassium, leading to hypokalemia.
Potassium is primarily lost through nasogastric suctioning.
The patient is developing acute kidney injury and cannot retain potassium.
Potassium is needed to buffer the rising glucose levels.

rationale.correct: This is a **Post-Insulin Potassium Shift (a1)**. In DKA, the serum potassium may appear elevated initially due to acidosis. However, IV insulin facilitates potassium's movement from the extracellular space (blood) into the intracellular space (cells). This can lead to a rapid decrease in serum potassium levels. The **U-waves** on the EKG (1215) are indicative of hypokalemia. Potassium supplementation is crucial to prevent potentially lethal arrhythmias.
clinicalPearls: DKA Management: Initiate potassium supplementation when serum potassium levels are < 5.0 mEq/L.
Insulin, glucose, and bicarbonate promote potassium's intracellular shift.

questionTrap.trap: Assuming the admission potassium level of 5.8 mEq/L indicates adequate potassium stores.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Recognize the difference between serum potassium levels (what is measured) and total body potassium stores. DKA patients are often potassium-depleted due to polyuria, even if serum levels appear normal or elevated initially.

mnemonic.title: K-In
mnemonic.expansion: Insulin puts the K-IN (Into the cell, out of the blood).

exhibits.title: EKG Strip (1215)
exhibits.content: Finding: Presence of **U-waves** directly after the T-wave. Flattened T-waves. Frequent Premature Ventricular Contractions (PVCs).

exhibits.title: Metabolic Log
exhibits.content: Note: Acidosis (High H+) causes potassium to shift out of cells into the blood. As insulin is administered and pH improves, hydrogen ions leave the cells, and potassium shifts **back inside**, potentially leading to a rapid decrease in serum potassium levels.
